subject: Why do the mods allow the BBBY general to stay up?
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread reveals a deep schism between those who believe the bankrupt BBBY stock is part of an elaborate merger scheme involving new entities and warrants, promising a short squeeze, and those who view these believers as delusional 'bagholders' who have lost everything. It highlights the persistence of retail investor 'cult' behavior and conspiracy theories even after conventional financial defeat, fueled by technical jargon and accusations of 'paid stock bashers.'
top_quote: The reason for this seethe thread is that BBBY (formerly Overstock) and 20230930-DK-Butterfly (formerly BBBY) are in the process of a merger as proved by the issuance of warrants BBBY-WT by BBBY/OSTK using the unique issuer code/CUSIP-6 identifier for BBBY/20230930-DK-Butterfly. A quick analogy to understand the concept succinctly: The ticker that a stock trades under is just shorthand for easy human reference much like a DNS for a website. Just as the real connection to a website is not the URL but the IP address, the real connection to a security for the settlement system that underpins global finance is the CUSIP number. >CUSIP-6 for BBBY/OSTK 690370 >CUSIP for BBBY/OSTK shares 690370106 >CUSIP-6 for 20230930-DK-Butterfly 075896 >CUSIP for cancelled shares of 20230930-DK-Butterfly 075896100 >CUSIP for BBBY-WT warrants issued by BBBY/OSTK 075896159 As you can see, the CUSIP-6 for BBBY-WT proves that BBBY/OSTK and BBBY/20230930-DK-Butterfly are in the process of a merger. The value of the merger is in the ~$1.7B in NOL carry forwards which will reduce the tax burden up to 80% per year until depleted. Paid stock bashers hired by the people who shorted BBBY/20230930-DK-Butterfly into bankruptcy have infested every online space where the subject is discussed because all of those shorts will be realized upon completion of the merger. Now while the shares of 20230930-DK-Butterfly have been cancelled, the interests formerly represented by those cancelled shares can be issued new shares in the post-merger entity. Indeed cancelling shares is a routine part of every merger. For example. BBBY/OSTK just announced a merger with TBHC (formerly Kirkland's) under which the shares of TBHC will be cancelled and TBHC shareholders will receive 0.2 shares of BBBY for every share of TBHC. So who cares? The trade is locked in, right? Wrong. That's why the paid stock bashers are here. BBBY currently trades for ~$5.84 and BBBY-WT currently trades for ~$0.67.

>What language can the world's richest people speak? What language does the majority of the world's wealth understand?

>What language are laws made and enforced?

>If fusion were developed today, what language would the results be published in first for the world?
>What language have the most influential books in the last 200 years been written? What language is spoken in the greatest movies?
>What language are most programming languages written?

Basically it's pretty obviously English. Expand your vocabulary and get good at expressing yourself. Latin and Greek are helpful in understanding original Western thought and also aiding further understanding of English.

Spanish is a servant's language. Anyone who speaks French (and there's globally not many of them) and matters also speaks English.. There's a billion Chinese speakers but they're either poor or craving English.

subject: Does anyone truly understand MSTR?
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread is a collective attempt to deconstruct MicroStrategy's complex financial strategy, which essentially leverages debt (especially zero-interest convertible bonds) and equity issuance to accumulate Bitcoin. It highlights MSTR as a highly volatile, leveraged bet on Bitcoin's appreciation, seen by some as genius arbitrage and by others as a precarious 'ponzi scheme' vulnerable to market downturns or loss of volatility.
top_quote: Imagine you have a lemonade stand. You tell people "Give me $10 now, and I'll give you $10 back in 5 years - no extra money needed!" People give you their $10 bills. You take that money and buy magic beans that keep growing bigger and more valuable. When 5 years pass, those magic beans are now worth $40. You sell a tiny piece of them to pay back the $10, and you keep $30 as pure profit. The key trick: He's borrowing money at 0% interest (free money!) and using it to buy Bitcoin, betting that Bitcoin will go up so much in value that when he has to pay people back, it's no big deal - he'll have made way more profit. Why people give him free money: They're giving him 0% loans (convertible bonds) because they hope to convert that loan into MicroStrategy stock later if the stock price goes up. They're basically betting on his Bitcoin bet.
image_analysis: The image shows Michael Saylor, CEO of MicroStrategy, sitting and looking pensive or concerned, with a small microphone attached to his cheek.

subject: Why havent altcoins pumped in 5 years?
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread reveals widespread disillusionment and fatigue among altcoin investors, who perceive a prolonged period of underperformance and question the viability of future "alt seasons." The underlying sentiment is that the crypto market has matured, becoming less hospitable to speculative 10x altcoin gains and more dominated by Bitcoin and institutional influences.
top_quote: Crypto has been easily accessible to the public for years now through exchanges and even normie apps like robinhood. Anyone interested has already bought, the frontier days are over. Third worlders will slowly buy into crypto as they get internet access, so we can expect a upward trend over time in bitcoin even after crash cycles. But the situation is similar to computer hardware, when the tech was new there was tons of diversity in products. The first consumers were discerning and picked their products based off a long checklist because they were auteurs of their hobby. Soon after as it became more mainstream the public settled mostly on Apple and Microsoft systems. There were guys back then at the time who thought the same as you, "The new Commodore Amiga will surely make a breakthrough in the market with how advanced it is compared to the other products!". And then nothing happened because 95% of the consumers were normies who didn't care and couldn't be swayed from their already help preferences. Stop hoping for a 10x in some altcoin, it's not going to happen. Buy and hold bitcoin like boomers do the S&P 500 and in 30 years you'll be fine. If that's not fast enough then rugpull some indians or something. Find a new investment other than crypto maybe, idk. But you gotta be able to recognize when the party is over if you're gonna invest in anything.
image_analysis: A highly distorted and wide-eyed Pepe the Frog meme, conveying extreme shock, panic, and mental anguish, fitting the thread's sentiment of market despair and investor fatigue.
